ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I found this class to be both uninspiring and inapplicable to what I am interested in.
The class provided a great opportunity to delve deeper in watershed processes and attempt to understand complex problems at the edge of what we know or think we know...

It is difficult to comment on how well the instructors taught the course because the instructors didn't actually teach the course. It is a course taught almost entirely by students. Frankly I think it was a waste of resources to have two instructors and a TA for this course. During most class sessions the instructors sat amongst the students and participated in discussions minimally.

A forest hydrology course is essential to this program and I was very happy that this course was provided this semester. The profs seemed a bit like they didn't understand the readings sometimes which made some discussions a bit tricky.Good articles, if not a bit dense to get through sometimesThe speakers were great overall. I like this model of class.
Field trips would've been great. Would've liked a more interesting set of assignments. You didn't need to understand the papers to write the responses.
I think this is a great idea for an advanced course and should be taught each semester, just changing the specialty/ field.

Most of the time, the bi-weekly readings were interesting and useful, but I did wish the professors and/or the TA had vetted some of the articles more carefully beforehand, as there were certain ones which were either impossibly dense or seemingly unrelated to the week's topic.I also wish the professors and/or the TA had done more prep work with the visiting speakers so that the speakers could have discussed the topic which we had read about beforehand. Generally the visiting speakers spent most of their time presenting about an altogether different topic (usually whatever their current research focused on). Not that those topics were uninteresting, it just felt like a lost opportunity since we were really quite prepared to discuss the topic which we had read about.My primary comment about this course, however, is my disappointment in the total absence of professor lectures. I knew the course was going to be rooted in journal articles, but I was really hoping for at least some participation from the professors. I was often confused about some of the basic hydrological/biogeochemical principles underlying the article content, and wished there had been a little more background instruction. The student presentations rarely accomplished this task, the TA was not readily available for outside help, and the professors did not provide any background reference materials for those of us that may have desired it. The few times Professor Saiers jumped in to address a question were very valuable, I just wished that had occurred more often.
A few of the speakers led engaging lectures, however, about half of the speakers were hard to follow and uninteresting.
The opportunity to consider watershed topics in depth and hear from some of the leading researchers in the country.

The instructors invited highly respected and well-known researchers as guest lecturers. The course provided broad exposure to current research in hydrology and the opportunity to connect with a range of scientists in the field.
Hearing from experts in the field
Be exposed directly to researchers in other universities.
Readings, class discussions, getting to see what the cutting-edge research in watershed processes is all about
I liked the alternating schedule of class discussion/outside presenter.
Exposure to several professionals working within the field.

The format of this class was unusual. We read 3 papers and discussed one week, then the next week the author would jet in and talk to use about what we had read. It was great to concentrate on the primary literature and to meet the author and ask what about this, what about that, etc.
Mostly interesting papers.
I did like the style of reading the articles, writing about them, discussing them, and then being able to focus and understand what the speaker was talking about.
The guest speakers were interesting and helpful in clarifying and elaborating the concepts discussed in class.
Hearing from real scientists.
Despite my earlier comments, I learned a LOT from this course and am glad that I took it.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The class structure was awful. As experts in their fields, the professors should be teaching the subjects, particularly complex and difficult one. Instead, the class structure was such that students gave presentations on subjects that they knew very little about and guest speakers presented on extremely focused subjects with little relevance to an interdisciplinary impact-focused school like F&ES. What is the point of having professors if they don't teach?

I would have appreciated some ability to influence which speakers and which papers we read... unfortunately the topics were not all interesting too me. If the class had some choices we may have been able to maximize the "interesting" topics rather than have the professors dictate to us what there interests were.

Discussions of the readings chosen by each invited lecturer were never actually discussions and assignments functioned mainly as a way for the instructors to gauge whether students had read the assigned papers. There was little time left after a speaker's talk to engage in discussion.
Some work about the same topics, but from different authors would improve the learning.

The choice of topics. Few of the students seemed to be engaged in the papers that we discussed and the guest lecturers who joined the class. I think the choice of topics didn't reflect the management and applied focus of the student body.
maybe more of a focus on a specific watershed issue that relates to management

It would have been nice to have a little more mix of presenters - my favorite presenter was the first because he still seemed to be conducting research directly with students. Also, it would have been nice to have a female hydrologist present (given that females' work was frequently cited by their male counterparts).
Matching readings and presentations could be improved upon, though this is difficult if the speaker makes changes in presentations, available papers, etc.

The format of having students lead the discussion was useful, but I think there could have been more balance in terms of having the professors do some of the lecturing as well. I think I would have learned more if Raymond or Saiers took over a bit more.
More integrative assignments.

Discussions were extremely boring and often we would feel guilty if the discussion leaders asked a question we were not sure of and then no one could answer. I would have liked the instructors to take a more active role. It is good to have student involvement, but I would have liked to hear their academic perspective on the article, why it's important, and what they think could be improved. The style of a boring discussion where we tried to tear down the validity of the author's work seemed unhelpful for my learning.

The professors need to take a more active teaching role in the class. The class was presented initially as being a good but comprehensive overview of watershed hydrology for all students to take regardless of their background. But the professors did not help teach any of the necessary underlying concepts to bring the class up to speed. That was a disappointment, and made the class very challenging especially since some of the scientific readings for the course were very high level papers.
It should be smaller, and every student should be required to give a presentation.
See earlier comment.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: James Saiers was able to meet in preparation of presentations. I had very little interaction, however, with either of the professors or the TA.
All were very helpful
I didn't seek help from the instructors. The TA was very helpful working with students to structure student presentations of the material presented in the assigned papers.
Both were willing to help.
Never asked for help
great on both accounts
All three did a good job and were responsive to questions.
Great.
All very available.
They did not have much involvement. The TA was fine in helping coordinate the discussion planning.
The TA was available to some extent, and I'm sure the professors would have been as well but I never went to see them.
TA was very helpful when approached. Instructors are very nice, and seem knowledgeable, but might have been more engaged in the course.
Minimal.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course provided me with little, if any, useful tools for a management-focused career.
This course helped me delve deeper into watershed topics complimenting and building of of biogeochemistry, water resources, river restoration, and hydrology courses I had taken.

This course provided broad exposure to current research in hydrology and watershed processes. It functioned to make me better equipped to think about ecosystem processes at the scale of watersheds and to gain an understanding of methods used to address research questions.
The course helped me to understand specific processes, to know where is the frontier of knowledge in this area, and to understand some management applications.
I think primary literature review is essential for any environmental management program.
The course provided a good overview of issues in watershed processes for someone with limited experience.
Focusing on watershed restotaration so good to read relevant literature
I wanted a watershed course to teach me more about hydrology and watershed dynamics since I have been studying forests.

I just wanted to get a crash course in watershed hydrology, which I suppose I did, but I felt like I could have learned more had the class been better organized and taught more by the professors themselves.
provides greater understanding of hydrology, increased familiarity with published papers, advanced science course.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It fulfilled a requirement and I had few other alternatives.
I took this course to gain a better understanding of how current and recent research approaches questions in the field and to gain new tools for my own future research.
Filled a requirement
To be exposed to the most advanced studies in watershed processes.
To get more practice reading and reviewing scientific studies.
To fill a gap in my land management knowledge.
Because I wanted the experience of directed readings of primary scientific literature.
For a on to my focal area.
I know that water is such an important part of ecosystem functioning. I wanted more experience and exposure to that aspect.
Interested in learning more about hydrology, want to take science courses and there aren't many at FES.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: No, this course was the worst course I took at FES.
yes, most of the time it was very stimulating, some papers were exrutiatingly difficult to read but hey, that's why we're at yale right?

I expected the discussion portion of the course to involve discussion. It really never did, in part because the student-led component evolved to rely heavily on very structured presentations of material from the readings and in part because of the large size of the class.
Yes
No, mostly because the topics were not of interest to me.
Yes
Yes.
Assignments became cumbersome an not challenging.
it gave me some more knowledge but not as much as I'd hoped
Somewhat, although not entirely. I could have learned more and gotten out of it more what I wanted had it not been as much discussion oriented but involved some lecture classes as well.
yes
See earlier comment.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: No, the course was much more hard core science-focused than I was expecting. I was thinking it would discuss management implications more than it did.
yes - I suppose I would have liked to have left with some more resources to take with me into my career..

Several of the invited lecturers gave really strong presentations. Many of the assigned readings presented interesting and relevant work. I expected this. I expected a discussion component that was largely supplanted by student presentations of reading material.
Yes, I am much more comfortable looking critically at a scientific study instead of taking it at face value (it's science - it must be true!).
Yes

I didn't know what to expect going in, but I found the class to be informative, educational, and interesting. Much of thetechnical material was beyond me, but it did deepen my understanding of the subject in general even if some of the details escaped me.
Yes
No, I would have liked to learn a lot more about the processes. I cant put a finger on it, but I feel like there was a lot more that could have been taught than just reviewing those papers.
Somewhat.
yes
See earlier comment.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: we were able to split up a difficult topic and tackle smaller aspects of it in order to provide a thorough and informative presentation

Group work usually functions to allow for more in-depth coverage of a topic and this was the case for this course. Working as a group with the TA to understand material with which we were unfamiliar was useful as well.
Working with the group helped me to clarify theconcepts.
A greater understanding of the literature and an increased ability to facilitate discussion during the class.
It was easier to learn harder material when I talked with my peers.
Advantage: you dont have to be responsible for everything. You can take advantage of the skills of each person and combine them.Disadvantage: some groups are less functional
Working with a small group to prepare a presentation for this course was an average experience. Not bad, not great.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: be prepared for some dense reading...but luckily it only comes every other week so just sit down and get into it write up your papers and there's no stress - just show up at class and have interesting conversations...
Take this course if you are seeking broad exposure to current research in the field and are interested in making connections to visiting researchers.

Consider whether you really want to take a class that is taught almost entirely by students and not the instructors. Also, make sure you know what the topics of each class will be before committing to the class.
Don't leave the critical reviews to the week that they're due.

Work with your fellow students to make sure the discussion sections are more useful, helpful, educational rather than boring and just ripping apart an article for the purpose of having something to talk about.
Ask the professors to do more teaching. Don't just let the class be strictly a discussion class. Make the teachers actually teach.
It's definitely a course where you get out of it what you put into it.
